FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][ScreenReader]NVDA is not announcing the warning suggestion before the reading the line under the Paket CLI command." (#9172) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Original: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1555446

Repro Steps:
Hit https://www.nuget.org and press Enter key.
Navigate to "Sign in" control and press Enter key 
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and press Enter key
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and press Enter key
6. Navigate to "Paket CLI" control and press Enter key
Verify that the screen reader is announcing warning suggestion under the paket CLI command or not.

Note:
Similar issue can be observed with the Narrator also.

Actual Result:
NVDA is not announcing the warning suggestion before the reading the line under the Paket CLI command.

Expected result:
NVDA should be announce the warning suggestion before the reading the line under the Paket CLI command.

User Impact:
Screen Reader Users may be get confused whether the warning suggestion is not announced by the screen reader.

Notes:
There is likely an HTML element getting ignored. If not, we can maybe fix this by adding an invisible element with the content we want read out.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: 500 - Internal Server Error when accessing certain package pages" (#9226) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact I'm unable to use NuGet.org ### Describe the bug If in the package's README, a specific scenario exists, attempting to access the package's page results in a 500 error. This issue comes to light with the added support of internal links in READMEs. The 500 error occurs as a result of an unhandled NullReferenceException. This may be a result of a separate bug within Markdig (auto-links or auto-identifiers or a combination of the two). ### Repro Steps The following scenario must exist in the README for this issue to occur. Scenario 1: ``` # Heading [Link Text [Heading]](URL) ``` Scenario 2: ``` # Heading [Heading] ``` ### Expected Behavior Accessing a page containing a README with either of the scenarios above should not result in a 500 error. The resulting HTML for scenario 1 should look like this: ```

Heading

Link Text [Heading]

``` The resulting HTML for scenario 2 should look like this: ```

Heading

[Heading]

``` ### Screenshots ![Screenshot 2022-09-07 151541](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25823466/189007584-1cd7dff7-935d-4abe-9617-c5e8a645a515.png) ### Additional Context and logs _No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Test:  `DOTNET_NUGET_SIGNATURE_VERIFICATION` tests run incorrectly on macOS" (#12147) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
While testing a branch that updates the test .NET SDK CLI from 6.0.400 to 7.0.100-rtm.22504.1, some tests failed on macOS but on no other OS.  (Note that not every test runs on every OS.)

* `Dotnet.Integration.Test.DotnetRestoreTests.DotnetRestore_WithUnSignedPackageAndSignatureValidationModeAsRequired_WithEnvVarTrue_Fails`
* `Dotnet.Integration.Test.DotnetRestoreTests.DotnetRestore_WithUnSignedPackageAndSignatureValidationModeAsRequired_WithEnvVarNameCaseSensitive_Succeed`
* `Dotnet.Integration.Test.DotnetRestoreTests.DotnetRestore_WithUnSignedPackageAndSignatureValidationModeAsRequired_WithEnvVarValueCaseInsensitive_Fails`

The reason is that when the last test runs, it sets the environment variable `DOTNET_NUGET_SIGNATURE_VERIFICATIOn` (note the casing of the last letter) to `xyz`, but the dotnet process that performs restore has 2 environment variables set:

```text
DOTNET_NUGET_SIGNATURE_VERIFICATION=true
DOTNET_NUGET_SIGNATURE_VERIFICATIOn=xyz
```

Despite having spent many hours debugging and inspecting code, the root cause is still unclear.  My best guess is that these tests are run in the same process and that there is a little lag between setting (or removing) environment variables and them becoming effective.  The result is that an environment variable set in a previous test leaks over into the next test.  Eventually, environment variables get unset, but not when we expect them to.

I've only observed this behavior on macOS.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Starred packages still show in the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab after uninstalling the NuGetRecommender" (#12143) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Release-6.0.x\6.0.2.26

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

## Repro steps:  
1. Open VS, click menu File->New Project, create a Console App (.Net Core) project. 
2. Open Manager Extensions (Extensions ->Manage Extensions ->Installed). 
3. Uninstall ‚ÄúNuGetRecommender‚Äù. 
4. Restart the previous project, open NuGet Package Manager UI.

## Expected: 
There is no starred package showing in the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71433406/194750382-ed4c3935-9a42-4a83-aa3c-67c3b60df0a1.png)
## Actual: 
There are still starred packages showing in the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71433406/194750405-341eeb6c-977f-43b9-8df9-024bdc29282e.png)

## Notes:
1. This issue reproes on D17.0\33005.84 + NuGet Client Release-6.0.x\6.0.2.26 and D17.2\33005.85 + NuGet Client Release-6.2.x\6.2.1.25.
2. It does not reproes on D16.11\33005.80 + NuGet Client Release-5.11.x\5.11.2.23.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Starred packages still show in the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab after disabling the NuGetRecommender" (#12144) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Release-6.2.x\6.2.1.25

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:
1.	Open VS, click menu File->New Project, create a Console App (.Net Core) project.
2.	Open Manager Extensions (Extensions ->Manage Extensions ->Installed).
3.	Click the ‚ÄúDisable‚Äù button on the right of ‚ÄúNuGetRecommender‚Äù when hovering on.
4.	Restart the previous project and open NuGet Package Manager UI.
#### Expected:
There is no starred package showing in the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab since the feature is disabled.
#### Actual:
There are still starred packages showing in the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/194752211-3379d667-9210-4f99-8c1a-252818137195.png)
#### Note:
1. It seems not a regression since it's a new PR change.
2. This issue reproes on D16.11\33005.80 + NuGet Client Release-5.11.x\5.11.2.23, D17.0\33005.84 + NuGet Client Release-6.0.x\6.0.2.26 and D17.2\33005.85 + NuGet Client Release-6.2.x\6.2.1.25.
### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: The ‚ÄúNuGetRecommender‚Äù still shows in the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab of ‚ÄúManage Extensions‚Äù after being uninstall and it can be uninstalled successfully for multiple times" (#12145) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

Release-6.2.x\6.2.1.25

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

1.	Open VS, click menu File->New Project, create a Console App (.Net Core) project.
2.	Click the menu: Extensions ->Manage Extensions ->Installed.
3.	Uninstall ‚ÄúNuGetRecommender‚Äù.
4.	Restart VS and reopen ‚ÄúManage Extensions‚Äù dialog.

#### Expected
The ‚ÄúNuGetRecommender‚Äù will not show in the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab of ‚ÄúManage Extensions‚Äù after being uninstall.

#### Actual
The ‚ÄúNuGetRecommender‚Äù still shows in the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab of ‚ÄúManage Extensions‚Äù after being uninstall and it can be uninstalled successfully for multiple times.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/194752980-8bcb1809-0f8b-472a-9ac2-d26141ffcc26.png)
#### Note
1.	It seems not a regression since it‚Äôs a new PR change.
2.	This issue reproes on D16.11\33005.80 + NuGet Client Release-5.11.x\5.11.2.23, D17.0\33005.84 + NuGet Client Release-6.0.x\6.0.2.26 and D17.2\33005.85 + NuGet Client Release-6.2.x\6.2.1.25.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: nuget.config next to .sln is only applied to csproj's in subfolders" (#12146) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

nuget

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

nuget.config next to solution only applies to *.csproj's thats under the subfolders from the solution. If a *.csproj that is placed with a seperate root is added to the solution, that will not pick up the same nuget.config.

/slnroot/Some.sln
/slnroot/nuget.config
/slnroot/Foo/Foo.csproj - includes the nuget.config
/seperateRoot/Bar/Bar.csproj - Does not include the nuget.config from `/slnroot/nuget.config`

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/configuring-nuget-behavior
Does say subfolders, but when its next to a Solution, and the Scope are `Solution`, I would expect it to work.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: An error ‚Äúunable to load the service index for source‚Äù occurs after making DevOps feed https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json enabled on Windows ARM64" (#11965) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

An error ‚Äúunable to load the service index for source‚Äù occurs after making DevOps feed https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json enable in PM UI


### Repro Steps

#### Details about Problem
VS Version: D17.3\32714.290
NuGet Version: Dev\6.3.0.123
System type: ARM-based 64bit processor
OS: Windows11 Pro 21H2

### Detailed repro steps
1. Create a C# Console App (.NET 6.0)/(.NET 7.0) in VS and open the PM UI of the solution. 
2. Add the DevOps feed (https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json) into the Settings->NuGet Package Manager->Package Sources. 
3. Select the new added DevOps feed in the Package source dropdown box in the PM UI. 

### Actual Result
An error ‚Äúunable to load the service index for source‚Äù occurs after making DevOps feed https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json enable as below.


### Expected Behavior
There is no error after making DevOps feed https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json enable.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/178227294-3a1a7295-dec8-4bb6-8f19-47291a5b451b.png)

### Additional Context and logs
#### The error log
Unable to load the service index for source https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json.
  Response status code does not indicate success: 401 (Unauthorized).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Transition from Symantec timestamping service to DigiCert timestamping service" (#64) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Between October 4th, 2022 and October 24, 2022 we will transition from the deprecated Symantec timestamping service currently in use to the DigiCert timestamping service for both Microsoft author signing and NuGet.org repository signing NuGet packages for new package submissions only.

*  October 4th ‚Äì October 24th:  Update NuGet.org repository signing to use http://timestamp.digicert.com/. Although all environments (DEV, INT, and PROD) will be updated during this window, http://nuget.org (PROD) specifically will be updated only near the beginning and end of this window.
*  October 18th ‚Äì 20th:  Update Microsoft author signing to use http://timestamp.digicert.com/.
 
We expect a smooth and quiet transition; however, if you have questions or concerns, either contact support@nuget.org or post [here](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9259).
 
Please see [dotnet/core#7688](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/7688) and [Proposal to re-enable signed NuGet package verification](https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2021/signed-package-verification/re-enable-signed-package-verification.md) for context.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Connection] Deprecating legacy cipher suites at www.nuget.org" (#63) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In order to provide a more secure and compliant environment for our customers, we are planning to deprecate legacy cipher suites and only support the following cipher suites at [www.nuget.org](http://www.nuget.org/):

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

Between 08/31/2022 07:00 PM UTC and 09/02/2022 07:00 PM UTC, we will take a test for this deprecation to understand the broken change for our customers. Based on our telemetry, we expect the impact to be minimal, but if you meet any connection issues at [www.nuget.org](http://www.nuget.org/) or have any questions, do reach out to us at‚ÄØ[support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org) or by commenting on the discussion issue: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9216. We will be closely monitoring our communication channels to assess any unexpected impact.
